    V-248632 - OL 8 must disable storing core dumps.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248632r779462_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Fail
    Version:OL08-00-010674
    Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
    Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

    A core dump includes a memory image taken at the time the operating system terminates an application. The memory image could contain sensitive data and is generally useful only for developers trying to debug problems. false
    Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to disable storing core dumps for all users.

    Add or modify the following line in "/etc/systemd/coredump.conf":

    Storage=none
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:170
    Result:false
    Title:OL08-00-010674 - OL 8 must disable storing core dumps.
    Description:It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

    A core dump includes a memory image taken at the time the operating system terminates an application. The memory image could contain sensitive data and is generally useful only for developers trying to debug problems.
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • false (All child checks must be true.)
      • false (storing core dumps is disabled)
    Tests:
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17000 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:storing core dumps is disabled
    Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
    Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17000 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • filepath must be equal to '/etc/systemd/coredump.conf'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*Storage\s*=\s*(\w*)\s*(?:#.*)?$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17000 (textfilecontent54_state)
    State Requirements:
    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to 'none'
    Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

    V-248633 - OL 8 must disable core dump backtraces.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248633r779465_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Fail
    Version:OL08-00-010675
    Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
    Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

    A core dump includes a memory image taken at the time the operating system terminates an application. The memory image could contain sensitive data and is generally useful only for developers trying to debug problems. false
    Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to disable core dump backtraces.

    Add or modify the following line in "/etc/systemd/coredump.conf":

    ProcessSizeMax=0
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:171
    Result:false
    Title:OL08-00-010675 - OL 8 must disable core dump backtraces.
    Description:It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

    A core dump includes a memory image taken at the time the operating system terminates an application. The memory image could contain sensitive data and is generally useful only for developers trying to debug problems.
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • false (All child checks must be true.)
      • false (core dump backtraces are disabled)
    Tests:
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17100 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:core dump backtraces are disabled
    Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
    Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17100 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • filepath must be equal to '/etc/systemd/coredump.conf'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*ProcessSizeMax\s*=\s*(\w*)\s*(?:#.*)?$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17100 (textfilecontent54_state)
    State Requirements:
    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '0'
    Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

    V-248644 - All OL 8 local interactive user accounts must be assigned a home directory upon creation.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248644r779498_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Pass
    Version:OL08-00-010760
    Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
    Description: If local interactive users are not assigned a valid home directory, there is no place for the storage and control of files they should own. false
    Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to assign home directories to all new local interactive users by setting the "CREATE_HOME" parameter in "/etc/login.defs" to "yes" as follows.

    CREATE_HOME yes
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:172
    Result:true
    Title:OL08-00-010760 - All OL 8 local interactive user accounts must be assigned a home directory upon creation.
    Description:If local interactive users are not assigned a valid home directory, there is no place for the storage and control of files they should own.
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • true (All child checks must be true.)
      • true (All OL8 local interactive user accounts are assigned a home directory upon creation)
    Tests:
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17200 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:true
    Title:All OL8 local interactive user accounts are assigned a home directory upon creation
    Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
    Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17200 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • filepath must be equal to '/etc/login.defs'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*CREATE_HOME\s+([^#\s]+)'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17200 (textfilecontent54_state)
    State Requirements:
    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to 'yes'
    Collected Item/State Result:
    [ true ]
    • filepath equals '/etc/login.defs'
    • path equals '/etc'
    • filename equals 'login.defs'
    • pattern equals '^\s*CREATE_HOME\s+([^#\s]+)'
    • instance equals '1'
    • text equals 'CREATE_HOME yes'
    • line equals 'CREATE_HOME yes'
    • subexpression equals 'yes'

    V-248652 - OL 8 systems below version 8.2 must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248652r853775_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Pass
    Version:OL08-00-020010
    Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
    CCI-002238 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 b)
    Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    OL 8 can use the "pam_faillock.so" for this purpose. Note that manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authselect" program.

    From "Pam_Faillock" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
    Fix Text:Add/modify the appropriate sections of the "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" and "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" files to match the following lines:

    auth required pam_faillock.so preauth dir=/var/log/faillock silent audit deny=3 even_deny_root fail_interval=900 unlock_time=0
    auth required pam_faillock.so authfail dir=/var/log/faillock unlock_time=0
    account required pam_faillock.so

    The "sssd" service must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the "sssd" service, run the following command:

    $ sudo systemctl restart sssd.service
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:174
    Result:true
    Title:OL08-00-020010 - OL 8 systems below version 8.2 must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.
    Description:By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    OL 8 can use the "pam_faillock.so" for this purpose. Note that manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authselect" program.

    From "Pam_Faillock" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • true (check maximum failed login attempts allowed in /etc/pam.d/system-auth (authfail))
        • false (check maximum failed login attempts allowed in /etc/pam.d/system-auth (preauth))
        • true (check account in /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
        • true (check maximum failed login attempts allowed in /etc/pam.d/password-auth (authfail))
        • false (check maximum failed login attempts allowed in /etc/pam.d/password-auth (preauth))
        • true (check account in /etc/pam.d/password-auth)
      • true (The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.)
    Tests:
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17400 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:true
    Title:check maximum failed login attempts allowed in /etc/pam.d/system-auth (authfail)
    Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
    Check:Result is based on check existence only.
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17400 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*auth\s+required\s+pam_faillock\.so\s+authfail(?:[ \t]+.*)?$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    Collected Item/State Result:
    [ not evaluated ]
    • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
    • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
    • filename equals 'system-auth'

    • line equals 'auth required pam_faillock.so authfail'
    • subexpression does not exist

    State Operator:All item-state comparisons must be true.

    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*auth\s+required\s+pam_faillock\.so\s+preauth.*[ \t]+deny=([0-9]+)(?:[ \t]+.*)?$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17400 (textfilecontent54_state)

    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '3'

    V-248653 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248653r853776_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Fail
    Version:OL08-00-020011
    Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
    CCI-002238 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 b)
    Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the "pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in "/etc/passwd" and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

    From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
    Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

    Add/modify the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file to match the following line:

    deny = 3
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:175
    Result:false
    Title:OL08-00-020011 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.
    Description:By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the "pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in "/etc/passwd" and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

    From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • false (The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.)
      • false (check /etc/security/faillock.conf for the deny setting value)
    Tests:
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17500 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.
    Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
    Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17500 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • path must be equal to '/etc'
    • filename must be equal to 'os-release'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:(\d+)\b'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17501 (textfilecontent54_state)
    State Requirements:
    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than '2'
    Collected Item/State Result:
    [ false ]
    • filepath equals '/etc/os-release'
    • path equals '/etc'
    • filename equals 'os-release'
    • pattern equals '^\s*CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:(\d+)\b'
    • instance equals '1'
    • text equals 'CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:8'
    • line equals 'CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:8'
    • subexpression equals '8'
    • subexpression equals '8'
    Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
    subexpression
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17501 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:check /etc/security/faillock.conf for the deny setting value
    Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
    Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
    State Operator:All item-state comparisons must be true.
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17501 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/faillock.conf'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*deny\s*=\s*([\d]+)\s*$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17500 (textfilecontent54_state)
    State Requirements:
    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '3'
    State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17502 (textfilecontent54_state)
    State Requirements:
    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than '0'
    Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

    V-248654 - OL 8 systems below version 8.2 must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248654r853777_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Pass
    Version:OL08-00-020012
    Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
    CCI-002238 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 b)
    Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    OL 8 can use the "pam_faillock.so" for this purpose. Note that manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authselect" program.

    From "Pam_Faillock" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
    Fix Text:Configure the operating system to lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur in 15 minutes.

    Add/modify the appropriate sections of the "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" and "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" files to match the following lines:

    auth required pam_faillock.so preauth dir=/var/log/faillock silent audit deny=3 even_deny_root fail_interval=900 unlock_time=0
    auth required pam_faillock.so authfail dir=/var/log/faillock unlock_time=0
    account required pam_faillock.so

    The "sssd" service must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the "sssd" service, run the following command:

    $ sudo systemctl restart sssd.service
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:

    Result:true
    Title:OL08-00-020012 - OL 8 systems below version 8.2 must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.
    Description:By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    OL 8 can use the "pam_faillock.so" for this purpose. Note that manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authselect" program.

    From "Pam_Faillock" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (check maximum failed login attempts allowed in /etc/pam.d/system-auth (authfail))

      • true (The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.)
    Tests:
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17600 (textfilecontent54_test)

    State Operator:All item-state comparisons must be true.

    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than '0'
    Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17601 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:check maximum failed login attempts allowed in /etc/pam.d/password-auth (authfail)
    Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
    Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
    State Operator:All item-state comparisons must be true.
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17601 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/password-auth'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*auth\s+required\s+pam_faillock\.so\s+preauth.*[ \t]+fail_interval=([0-9]+)(?:[ \t]+.*)?$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17600 (textfilecontent54_state)
    State Requirements:
    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '900'
    State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17602 (textfilecontent54_state)
    State Requirements:
    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than '0'
    Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17406 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:true
    Title:The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.
    Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
    Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17406 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • path must be equal to '/etc'
    • filename must be equal to 'os-release'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:(\d+)\b'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17401 (textfilecontent54_state)
    State Requirements:
    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than or equal to '2'
    Collected Item/State Result:
    [ true ]
    • filepath equals '/etc/os-release'
    • path equals '/etc'
    • filename equals 'os-release'
    • pattern equals '^\s*CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:(\d+)\b'
    • instance equals '1'
    • text equals 'CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:8'
    • line equals 'CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:8'
    • subexpression equals '8'
    • subexpression equals '8'

    V-248655 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248655r853778_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Fail
    Version:OL08-00-020013
    Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
    CCI-002238 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 b)
    Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the "pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in "/etc/passwd" and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

    From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
    Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

    Add/modify the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file to match the following line:

    fail_interval = 900
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:177
    Result:false
    Title:OL08-00-020013 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.
    Description:By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the "pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in "/etc/passwd" and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

    From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • false (The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.)
      • false (check /etc/security/faillock.conf for the fail_interval setting value)
    Tests:
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17700 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.
    Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
    Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17500 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • path must be equal to '/etc'
    • filename must be equal to 'os-release'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:(\d+)\b'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17501 (textfilecontent54_state)
    State Requirements:
    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than '2'
    Collected Item/State Result:
    [ false ]
    • filepath equals '/etc/os-release'
    • path equals '/etc'
    • filename equals 'os-release'
    • pattern equals '^\s*CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:(\d+)\b'
    • instance equals '1'
    • text equals 'CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:8'
    • line equals 'CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:8'
    • subexpression equals '8'
    • subexpression equals '8'
    Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
    subexpression
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17701 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:check /etc/security/faillock.conf for the fail_interval setting value
    Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
    Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17700 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/faillock.conf'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*fail_interval\s*=\s*([\d]+)\s*$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17700 (textfilecontent54_state)
    State Requirements:
    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than or equal to '900'
    Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

    V-248656 - OL 8 systems below version 8.2 must automatically lock an account until the locked account is released by an administrator when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248656r853779_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Pass
    Version:OL08-00-020014
    Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
    CCI-002238 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 b)
    Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    OL 8 can use the "pam_faillock.so" for this purpose. Note that manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authselect" program.

    From "Pam_Faillock" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
    Fix Text:Configure the operating system to lock an account until released by an administrator when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur in 15 minutes.

    Add/modify the appropriate sections of the "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" and "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" files to match the following lines:

    auth required pam_faillock.so preauth dir=/var/log/faillock silent audit deny=3 even_deny_root fail_interval=900 unlock_time=0
    auth required pam_faillock.so authfail dir=/var/log/faillock unlock_time=0
    account required pam_faillock.so

    The "sssd" service must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the "sssd" service, run the following command:

    $ sudo systemctl restart sssd.service
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:178
    Result:true
    Title:OL08-00-020014 - OL 8 systems below version 8.2 must automatically lock an account until the locked account is released by an administrator when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.
    Description:By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    OL 8 can use the "pam_faillock.so" for this purpose. Note that manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authselect" program.

    From "Pam_Faillock" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (check unlock_time is set to 0 in /etc/pam.d/system-auth (preauth))
        • false (check unlock_time is set to 0 in /etc/pam.d/password-auth (preauth))
        • false (check unlock_time is set to 0 in /etc/pam.d/system-auth (authfail))
        • false (check unlock_time is set to 0 in /etc/pam.d/password-auth (authfail))
      • true (The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.)
    Tests:
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17800 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:check unlock_time is set to 0 in /etc/pam.d/system-auth (preauth)
    Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
    Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17800 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*auth\s+required\s+pam_faillock\.so\s+preauth.*[ \t]+unlock_time=([0-9]+)(?:[ \t]+.*)?$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17800 (textfilecontent54_state)
    State Requirements:
    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '0'
    Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17801 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:check unlock_time is set to 0 in /etc/pam.d/password-auth (preauth)
    Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
    Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17801 (textfilecontent54_object)

    • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/password-auth'

    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

    V-248660 - OL 8 systems below version 8.2 must prevent system messages from being presented when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248660r853783_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Pass
    Version:OL08-00-020018
    Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
    CCI-002238 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 b)
    Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    OL 8 can use the "pam_faillock.so" for this purpose. Note that manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authselect" program.

    From "Pam_Faillock" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
    Fix Text:Configure the operating system to prevent informative messages from being presented at logon attempts.

    Add/modify the appropriate sections of the "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" and "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" files to match the following lines:

    auth required pam_faillock.so preauth dir=/var/log/faillock silent audit deny=3 even_deny_root fail_interval=900 unlock_time=0
    auth required pam_faillock.so authfail dir=/var/log/faillock unlock_time=0
    account required pam_faillock.so

    The "sssd" service must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the "sssd" service, run the following command:

    $ sudo systemctl restart sssd.service
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:180
    Result:true
    Title:OL08-00-020018 - OL 8 systems below version 8.2 must prevent system messages from being presented when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.
    Description:By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    OL 8 can use the "pam_faillock.so" for this purpose. Note that manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authselect" program.

    From "Pam_Faillock" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • true (All child checks must be true.)
        • true (check silent is set in /etc/pam.d/system-auth (preauth))
        • true (check silent is set in /etc/pam.d/password-auth (preauth))
      • true (The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.)
    Tests:
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:18001 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:true
    Title:check silent is set in /etc/pam.d/system-auth (preauth)
    Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
    Check:Result is based on check existence only.
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:18000 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*auth\s+required\s+pam_faillock\.so\s+preauth.*[ \t]+silent(?:[ \t]+.*)?$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    Collected Item/State Result:
    [ not evaluated ]
    • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
    • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
    • filename equals 'system-auth'
    • pattern equals '^\s*auth\s+required\s+pam_faillock\.so\s+preauth.*[ \t]+silent(?:[ \t]+.*)?$'
    • instance equals '1'
    • text equals 'auth required pam_faillock.so preauth silent'
    • line equals 'auth required pam_faillock.so preauth silent'
    • subexpression does not exist
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:18002 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:true
    Title:check silent is set in /etc/pam.d/password-auth (preauth)
    Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
    Check:Result is based on check existence only.
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:18001 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/password-auth'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*auth\s+required\s+pam_faillock\.so\s+preauth.*[ \t]+silent(?:[ \t]+.*)?$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    Collected Item/State Result:
    [ not evaluated ]
    • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/password-auth'
    • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
    • filename equals 'password-auth'
    • pattern equals '^\s*auth\s+required\s+pam_faillock\.so\s+preauth.*[ \t]+silent(?:[ \t]+.*)?$'
    • instance equals '1'
    • text equals 'auth required pam_faillock.so preauth silent'
    • line equals 'auth required pam_faillock.so preauth silent'
    • subexpression does not exist

    • filename must be equal to 'os-release'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:(\d+)\b'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

    State Requirements:
    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than or equal to '2'
    Collected Item/State Result:
    [ true ]
    • filepath equals '/etc/os-release'
    • path equals '/etc'
    • filename equals 'os-release'
    • pattern equals '^\s*CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:(\d+)\b'
    • instance equals '1'
    • text equals 'CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:8'
    • line equals 'CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:8'
    • subexpression equals '8'
    • subexpression equals '8'

    V-248661 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must prevent system messages from being presented when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248661r853784_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Fail
    Version:OL08-00-020019
    Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
    CCI-002238 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 b)
    Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the" pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in "/etc/passwd" and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

    From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
    Fix Text:Configure the operating system to prevent informative messages from being presented at logon attempts.

    Add/modify the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file to match the following line:

    silent
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:181
    Result:false
    Title:OL08-00-020019 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must prevent system messages from being presented when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.
    Description:By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the" pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in "/etc/passwd" and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

    From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • false (The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.)
      • false (check /etc/security/faillock.conf for the silent setting value)
    Tests:
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:18100 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.
    Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
    Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17500 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • path must be equal to '/etc'
    • filename must be equal to 'os-release'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:(\d+)\b'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17501 (textfilecontent54_state)
    State Requirements:
    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than '2'
    Collected Item/State Result:
    [ false ]
    • filepath equals '/etc/os-release'
    • path equals '/etc'
    • filename equals 'os-release'
    • pattern equals '^\s*CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:(\d+)\b'
    • instance equals '1'
    • text equals 'CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:8'
    • line equals 'CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:8'
    • subexpression equals '8'
    • subexpression equals '8'
    Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
    subexpression
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:18101 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:check /etc/security/faillock.conf for the silent setting value
    Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
    Check:Result is based on check existence only.
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:18100 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/faillock.conf'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*silent\s*$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

    V-248662 - OL 8 systems below version 8.2 must log user name information when unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248662r853785_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Pass
    Version:OL08-00-020020
    Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
    CCI-002238 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 b)
    Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    OL 8 can use the "pam_faillock.so" for this purpose. Note that manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authselect" program.

    From "Pam_Faillock" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
    Fix Text:Configure the operating system to log user name information when unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

    Add/modify the appropriate sections of the "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" and "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" files to match the following lines:

    auth required pam_faillock.so preauth dir=/var/log/faillock silent audit deny=3 even_deny_root fail_interval=900 unlock_time=0
    auth required pam_faillock.so authfail dir=/var/log/faillock unlock_time=0
    account required pam_faillock.so

    The "sssd" service must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the "sssd" service, run the following command:

    $ sudo systemctl restart sssd.service
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:182
    Result:true
    Title:OL08-00-020020 - OL 8 systems below version 8.2 must log user name information when unsuccessful logon attempts occur.
    Description:By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    OL 8 can use the "pam_faillock.so" for this purpose. Note that manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authselect" program.

    From "Pam_Faillock" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (check audit is set in /etc/pam.d/system-auth (preauth))
        • false (check audit is set in /etc/pam.d/password-auth (preauth))
      • true (The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.)
    Tests:
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:18200 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:check audit is set in /etc/pam.d/system-auth (preauth)
    Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
    Check:Result is based on check existence only.
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:18200 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*auth\s+required\s+pam_faillock\.so\s+preauth.*[ \t]+audit(?:[ \t]+.*)?$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:18201 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:check audit is set in /etc/pam.d/password-auth (preauth)
    Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
    Check:Result is based on check existence only.
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:18201 (textfilecontent54_object)

    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*auth\s+required\s+pam_faillock\.so\s+preauth.*[ \t]+audit(?:[ \t]+.*)?$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

    V-248664 - OL 8 systems below version 8.2 must include root when automatically locking an account until the locked account is released by an administrator when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248664r853787_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Pass
    Version:OL08-00-020022
    Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
    CCI-002238 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 b)
    Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    OL 8 can use the "pam_faillock.so" for this purpose. Note that manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authselect" program.

    From "Pam_Faillock" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
    Fix Text:Configure the operating system to include root when locking an account after three unsuccessful logon attempts occur in 15 minutes.

    Add/modify the appropriate sections of the "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" and "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" files to match the following lines:

    auth required pam_faillock.so preauth dir=/var/log/faillock silent audit deny=3 even_deny_root fail_interval=900 unlock_time=0
    auth required pam_faillock.so authfail dir=/var/log/faillock unlock_time=0
    account required pam_faillock.so

    The "sssd" service must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the "sssd" service, run the following command:

    $ sudo systemctl restart sssd.service
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:

    V-248665 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must include root when automatically locking an account until the locked account is released by an administrator when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248665r853788_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Fail
    Version:OL08-00-020023
    Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
    CCI-002238 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 b)
    Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the "pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in /etc/passwd and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

    From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
    Fix Text:Configure the operating system to include root when locking an account after three unsuccessful logon attempts occur in 15 minutes.

    Add/modify the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file to match the following line:

    even_deny_root
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:185
    Result:false
    Title:OL08-00-020023 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must include root when automatically locking an account until the locked account is released by an administrator when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.
    Description:By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

    In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the "pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in /etc/passwd and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

    From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • false (The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.)
      • false (check /etc/security/faillock.conf for the even_deny_root setting)

    Result:false

    Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
    Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).

    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

    • instance equals '1'

    • line equals 'CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:8'

    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*even_deny_root\s*$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

    V-248674 - OL 8 must have the tmux package installed.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248674r779588_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Fail
    Version:OL08-00-020039
    Identities:CCI-000056 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11.1 (iii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-11 b)
    CCI-000058 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 a)
    Description: A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

    The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. Rather than be forced to wait for a period of time to expire before the user session can be locked, OL 8 needs to provide users with the ability to manually invoke a session lock so users can secure their session if it is necessary to temporarily vacate the immediate physical vicinity.

    Tmux is a terminal multiplexer that enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000028-GPOS-00009, SRG-OS-000030-GPOS-00011 false
    Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enable a user to initiate a session lock via tmux.

    Install the "tmux" package, if it is not already installed, by running the following command:

    $ sudo yum install tmux
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:187
    Result:false
    Title:OL08-00-020039 - OL 8 must have the tmux package installed.
    Description:A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

    The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. Rather than be forced to wait for a period of time to expire before the user session can be locked, OL 8 needs to provide users with the ability to manually invoke a session lock so users can secure their session if it is necessary to temporarily vacate the immediate physical vicinity.

    Tmux is a terminal multiplexer that enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000028-GPOS-00009, SRG-OS-000030-GPOS-00011
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • false (All child checks must be true.)
      • false (The tmux package is installed)
    Tests:
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:18700 (rpminfo_test)
    Result:false
    Title:The tmux package is installed
    Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
    Check:Result is based on check existence only.
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:18700 (rpminfo_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • name must be equal to 'tmux'
    Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

    V-248675 - OL 8 must enable a user session lock until that user re-establishes access using established identification and authentication procedures for command line sessions.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248675r902786_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Fail
    Version:OL08-00-020040
    Identities:CCI-000056 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11.1 (iii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-11 b)
    CCI-000058 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 a)
    Description: A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

    The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. Rather than be forced to wait for a period of time to expire before the user session can be locked, OL 8 needs to provide users with the ability to manually invoke a session lock so users can secure their session if it is necessary to temporarily vacate the immediate physical vicinity.

    Tmux is a terminal multiplexer that enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000028-GPOS-00009, SRG-OS-000030-GPOS-00011 false
    Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enable a user to manually initiate a session lock via tmux. This configuration binds the uppercase letter "X" to manually initiate a session lock after the prefix key "Ctrl + b" has been sent. The complete key sequence is thus "Ctrl + b" then "Shift + x" to lock tmux.

    Create a global configuration file "/etc/tmux.conf" and add the following lines:

    set -g lock-command vlock
    bind X lock-session

    Reload tmux configuration to take effect. This can be performed in tmux while it is running:

    $ tmux source-file /etc/tmux.conf
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8os:def:248675
    Result:false
    Title:OL08-00-020040 - OL 8 must enable a user session lock until that user re-establishes access using established identification and authentication procedures for command line sessions.
    Description:A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

    The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. Rather than be forced to wait for a period of time to expire before the user session can be locked, OL 8 needs to provide users with the ability to manually invoke a session lock so users can secure their session if it is necessary to temporarily vacate the immediate physical vicinity.

    Tmux is a terminal multiplexer that enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000028-GPOS-00009, SRG-OS-000030-GPOS-00011
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • false (All child checks must be true.)
      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (The lock-command is set in /etc/tmux.conf)
        • false (The lock-session is bound to X, in /etc/tmux.conf)
    Tests:
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:23034800 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:The lock-command is set in /etc/tmux.conf
    Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
    Check:Result is based on check existence only.
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:23034800 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • filepath must be equal to '/etc/tmux.conf'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*set\s+-g\s+lock-command\s+vlock\s*(?:#.*)?$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:23034801 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:The lock-session is bound to X, in /etc/tmux.conf
    Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
    Check:Result is based on check existence only.
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:23034801 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • filepath must be equal to '/etc/tmux.conf'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*bind\s+X\s+lock-session\s*(?:#.*)?$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

    V-248676 - OL 8 must ensure session control is automatically started at shell initialization.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248676r880538_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Fail
    Version:OL08-00-020041
    Identities:CCI-000056 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11.1 (iii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-11 b)
    CCI-000058 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 a)
    Description: A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

    The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. Rather than be forced to wait for a period of time to expire before the user session can be locked, OL 8 needs to provide users with the ability to manually invoke a session lock so users can secure their session if it is necessary to temporarily vacate the immediate physical vicinity.

    Tmux is a terminal multiplexer that enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen.

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000028-GPOS-00009, SRG-OS-000030-GPOS-00011 false
    Fix Text:Configure the operating system to initialize the tmux terminal multiplexer as each shell is called by adding the following lines to a custom.sh shell script in the /etc/profile.d/ directory:

    if [ "$PS1" ]; then
    parent=$(ps -o ppid= -p $$)
    name=$(ps -o comm= -p $parent)
    case "$name" in (sshd|login) tmux ;; esac
    fi

    This setting will take effect at next logon.
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:189
    Result:false
    Title:OL08-00-020041 - OL 8 must ensure session control is automatically started at shell initialization.
    Description:A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

    The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. Rather than be forced to wait for a period of time to expire before the user session can be locked, OL 8 needs to provide users with the ability to manually invoke a session lock so users can secure their session if it is necessary to temporarily vacate the immediate physical vicinity.

    Tmux is a terminal multiplexer that enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen.
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • false (All child checks must be true.)
      • false (/etc/profile.d/*.sh contains a shell script to initialize the tmux terminal multiplexer as each shell is called.)
      • false (The tmux process is running.)
    Tests:
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:18900 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:/etc/profile.d/*.sh contains a shell script to initialize the tmux terminal multiplexer as each shell is called.
    Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
    Check:Result is based on check existence only.
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:18900 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • path must be equal to '/etc/profile.d'
    • filename must match the pattern '\.sh$'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*if\s+\[\s*"\$PS1"\s*\];\s+then\s+parent=\$\(ps\s+-o\s+ppid=\s+-p\s+\$\$\)\s+name=\$\(ps\s+-o\s+comm=\s+-p\s+\$parent\)\s+case\s+"\$name"\s+in\s+\(sshd\|login\)\s+tmux\s+;;\s+esac\s+fi\s*$'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:18901 (process58_test)
    Result:false
    Title:The tmux process is running.
    Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
    Check:Result is based on check existence only.
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:18901 (process58_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • command_line must match the pattern '^(/usr/bin/)?tmux\b'
    • pid must be greater than '1'
    Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

    V-248686 - OL 8 must ensure the password complexity module is enabled in the password-auth file.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248686r902809_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Pass
    Version:OL08-00-020100
    Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
    Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. Use of "pwquality" enforces complex password construction configuration and has the ability to limit brute-force attacks on the system.

    OL 8 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. This is set in both of the following:
    /etc/pam.d/password-auth
    /etc/pam.d/system-auth

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000069-GPOS-00037, SRG-OS-000070-GPOS-00038 false
    Fix Text:Configure the operating system to use "pwquality" to enforce password complexity rules.

    Add the following line to the "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" file (or modify the line to have the required value):

    password requisite pam_pwquality.so
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8os:def:248686
    Result:true
    Title:OL08-00-020100 - OL 8 must ensure the password complexity module is enabled in the password-auth file.
    Description:Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. Use of "pwquality" enforces complex password construction configuration and has the ability to limit brute-force attacks on the system.

    OL 8 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. This is set in both of the following:
    /etc/pam.d/password-auth
    /etc/pam.d/system-auth

    Satisfies: SRG-OS-000069-GPOS-00037, SRG-OS-000070-GPOS-00038
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • true (All child checks must be true.)
      • true (All child checks must be true.)
        • true (The pam_pwquality module is included in password-auth.)
    Tests:
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:23035600 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:true
    Title:The pam_pwquality module is included in password-auth.
    Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
    Check:Result is based on check existence only.
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:23035600 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/password-auth'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:required|requisite)\s+pam_pwquality\.so\b'
    • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
    Collected Item/State Result:
    [ not evaluated ]
    • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/password-auth'
    • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
    • filename equals 'password-auth'
    • pattern equals '^\s*password\s+(?:required|requisite)\s+pam_pwquality\.so\b'
    • instance equals '1'
    • text equals '
      password requisite pam_pwquality.so'
    • line equals '
      password requisite pam_pwquality.so'
    • subexpression does not exist

    V-248690 - OL 8 must require the maximum number of repeating characters of the same character class be limited to four when passwords are changed.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248690r858637_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Fail
    Version:OL08-00-020140
    Identities:CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
    Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

    Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

    OL 8 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. The "maxclassrepeat" option sets the maximum number of allowed same consecutive characters in the same class in the new password. false
    Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to require the change of the number of repeating characters of the same character class when passwords are changed by setting the "maxclassrepeat" option.

    Add or update the following line in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" file or a configuration file in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf.d/" directory:

    maxclassrepeat = 4

    Remove any configurations that conflict with the above value.
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Oracle Linux 8
    Identifier:5416
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:195
    Result:false
    Title:OL08-00-020140 - OL 8 must require the maximum number of repeating characters of the same character class be limited to four when passwords are changed.
    Description:Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

    Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

    OL 8 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. The "maxclassrepeat" option sets the maximum number of allowed same consecutive characters in the same class in the new password.
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • false (All child checks must be true.)
      • false (the maximum number of repeating characters of the same character class must be limited to four when passwords are changed)
    Tests:
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:19500 (textfilecontent54_test)
    Result:false
    Title:the maximum number of repeating characters of the same character class must be limited to four when passwords are changed
    Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
    Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
    State Operator:All item-state comparisons must be true.
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:19502 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • Collect any available items.
    State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:19500 (textfilecontent54_state)
    State Requirements:
    • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '4'

    V-248691 - OL 8 must require the maximum number of repeating characters be limited to three when passwords are changed.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248691r858639_rule
    Test Type:Automated
    Result:Fail
    Version:OL08-00-020150
    Identities:CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
    Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

    Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

    OL 8 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. The "maxrepeat" option sets the maximum number of allowed same consecutive characters in a new password. false
    Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to require the change of the number of repeating consecutive characters when passwords are changed by setting the "maxrepeat" option.

    Add or update the following line in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" file or a configuration file in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf.d/" directory:

    maxrepeat = 3

    Remove any configurations that conflict with the above value.

    Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

    OL 8 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. The "maxrepeat" option sets the maximum number of allowed same consecutive characters in a new password.
