                V-248797 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "sudo" command.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248797r853830_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Fail
                Version:OL08-00-030550
                Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)
                CCI-000135 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3 (1).1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 (1))
                CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
                CCI-002884 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: MA-4 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: MA-4 (1) (a))
                Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "sudo" command allows a permitted user to execute a command as the superuser or another user as specified by the security policy.

                When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
                Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any use of the "sudo" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

                -a always,exit -F path=/usr/bin/sudo -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k priv_cmd

                The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                $ sudo service auditd restart
                Severity:medium
                Weight:10.0
                Reference:
                Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                Publisher:DISA
                Type:DPMS Target
                Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                Identifier:5416
                Definitions:
                Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:289
                Result:false
                Title:OL08-00-030550 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "sudo" command.
                Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "sudo" command allows a permitted user to execute a command as the superuser or another user as specified by the security policy.

                When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215
                Class:compliance
                Tests:
                • false (All child checks must be true.)
                  • false (Audit invocations of /usr/bin/sudo.)
                Tests:
                Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:28900 (textfilecontent54_test)
                Result:false
                Title:Audit invocations of /usr/bin/sudo.
                Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:28900 (textfilecontent54_object)
                Object Requirements:
                • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
                • for pattern, the following must be true:
                  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(?:always,exit|exit,always)(?:\s+-S\s+all)?\s+-F\s+path=/usr/bin/sudo\s+(?:-F\s+perm=[rwa]*x[rwa]*\s+)?-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)(?:\s+(?:-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
                • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                V-248798 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "usermod" command.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248798r853831_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Fail
                Version:OL08-00-030560
                Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)
                CCI-000135 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3 (1).1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 (1))
                CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
                CCI-002884 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: MA-4 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: MA-4 (1) (a))
                Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "usermod" command modifies the system account files to reflect the changes that are specified on the command line.

                When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
                Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any use of the "usermod" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

                -a always,exit -F path=/usr/sbin/usermod -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k privileged-usermod

                The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                $ sudo service auditd restart
                Severity:medium
                Weight:10.0
                Reference:
                Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                Publisher:DISA
                Type:DPMS Target
                Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                Identifier:5416
                Definitions:
                Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:290
                Result:false
                Title:OL08-00-030560 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "usermod" command.
                Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "usermod" command modifies the system account files to reflect the changes that are specified on the command line.

                When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215
                Class:compliance
                Tests:
                • false (All child checks must be true.)
                  • false (Audit invocations of /usr/sbin/usermod.)
                Tests:
                Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:29000 (textfilecontent54_test)
                Result:false
                Title:Audit invocations of /usr/sbin/usermod.
                Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:29000 (textfilecontent54_object)
                Object Requirements:
                • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
                • for pattern, the following must be true:
                  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(?:always,exit|exit,always)(?:\s+-S\s+all)?\s+-F\s+path=/usr/sbin/usermod\s+(?:-F\s+perm=[rwa]*x[rwa]*\s+)?-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)(?:\s+(?:-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
                • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                V-248799 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "chacl" command.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248799r853832_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Fail
                Version:OL08-00-030570
                Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)
                CCI-000135 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3 (1).1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 (1))
                CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
                CCI-002884 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: MA-4 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: MA-4 (1) (a))
                Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "chacl" command is used to change the access control list of a file or directory.

                When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
                Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any use of the "chacl" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

                -a always,exit -F path=/usr/bin/chacl -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_chng

                The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                $ sudo service auditd restart
                Severity:medium
                Weight:10.0
                Reference:
                Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                Publisher:DISA
                Type:DPMS Target
                Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                Identifier:5416
                Definitions:
                Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:291
                Result:false
                Title:OL08-00-030570 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "chacl" command.
                Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "chacl" command is used to change the access control list of a file or directory.

                When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215
                Class:compliance
                Tests:
                • false (All child checks must be true.)
                  • false (Audit invocations of /usr/bin/chacl.)
                Tests:
                Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:29100 (textfilecontent54_test)
                Result:false
                Title:Audit invocations of /usr/bin/chacl.
                Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:29100 (textfilecontent54_object)
                Object Requirements:

                • for pattern, the following must be true:
                  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(?:always,exit|exit,always)(?:\s+-S\s+all)?\s+-F\s+path=/usr/bin/chacl\s+(?:-F\s+perm=[rwa]*x[rwa]*\s+)?-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)(?:\s+(?:-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'

                V-248800 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "kmod" command.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248800r853833_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Fail
                Version:OL08-00-030580
                Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)
                CCI-000135 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3 (1).1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 (1))
                CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
                CCI-002884 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: MA-4 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: MA-4 (1) (a))
                Description: Without the capability to generate audit records, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "kmod" command is used to control Linux Kernel modules.

                The list of audited events is the set of events for which audits are to be generated. This set of events is typically a subset of the list of all events for which the system is capable of generating audit records.

                DoD has defined the list of events for which OL 8 will provide an audit record generation capability as the following:

                1) Successful and unsuccessful attempts to access, modify, or delete privileges, security objects, security levels, or categories of information (e.g., classification levels);

                2) Access actions, such as successful and unsuccessful logon attempts, privileged activities or other system-level access, starting and ending time for user access to the system, concurrent logons from different workstations, successful and unsuccessful accesses to objects, all program initiations, and all direct access to the information system;

                3) All account creations, modifications, disabling, and terminations; and

                4) All kernel module load, unload, and restart actions.

                Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00216, SRG-OS-000477-GPOS-00222 false
                Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to audit the execution of the module management program "kmod" by adding or updating the following line to "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules":

                -w /usr/bin/kmod -p x -k modules

                The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                $ sudo service auditd restart
                Severity:medium
                Weight:10.0
                Reference:
                Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                Publisher:DISA
                Type:DPMS Target
                Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                Identifier:5416
                Definitions:
                Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:292
                Result:false
                Title:OL08-00-030580 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "kmod" command.
                Description:Without the capability to generate audit records, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "kmod" command is used to control Linux Kernel modules.

                The list of audited events is the set of events for which audits are to be generated. This set of events is typically a subset of the list of all events for which the system is capable of generating audit records.

                DoD has defined the list of events for which OL 8 will provide an audit record generation capability as the following:

                1) Successful and unsuccessful attempts to access, modify, or delete privileges, security objects, security levels, or categories of information (e.g., classification levels);

                2) Access actions, such as successful and unsuccessful logon attempts, privileged activities or other system-level access, starting and ending time for user access to the system, concurrent logons from different workstations, successful and unsuccessful accesses to objects, all program initiations, and all direct access to the information system;

                3) All account creations, modifications, disabling, and terminations; and

                4) All kernel module load, unload, and restart actions.

                Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00216, SRG-OS-000477-GPOS-00222
                Class:compliance
                Tests:
                • false (All child checks must be true.)
                  • false (Audit executions of /usr/bin/kmod.)
                Tests:
                Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:29200 (textfilecontent54_test)
                Result:false
                Title:Audit executions of /usr/bin/kmod.
                Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:29200 (textfilecontent54_object)
                Object Requirements:
                • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
                • for pattern, the following must be true:
                  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-w\s+/usr/bin/kmod(?:\s+-p\s+[raw]*x[raw]*)?(?:\s+(?:-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
                • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                V-248802 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any attempted modifications to the "lastlog" file.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248802r853835_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Fail
                Version:OL08-00-030600
                Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)
                CCI-000135 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3 (1).1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 (1))
                CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
                CCI-002884 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: MA-4 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: MA-4 (1) (a))
                Description: Without the capability to generate audit records, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).

                The list of audited events is the set of events for which audits are to be generated. This set of events is typically a subset of the list of all events for which the system is capable of generating audit records.

                DoD has defined the list of events for which OL 8 will provide an audit record generation capability as the following:

                1) Successful and unsuccessful attempts to access, modify, or delete privileges, security objects, security levels, or categories of information (e.g., classification levels);

                2) Access actions, such as successful and unsuccessful logon attempts, privileged activities or other system-level access, starting and ending time for user access to the system, concurrent logons from different workstations, successful and unsuccessful accesses to objects, all program initiations, and all direct access to the information system;

                3) All account creations, modifications, disabling, and terminations; and

                4) All kernel module load, unload, and restart actions.

                Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215, SRG-OS-000473-GPOS-00218 false
                Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any attempted modifications to the "lastlog" file by adding or updating the following rules in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

                -w /var/log/lastlog -p wa -k logins

                The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                $ sudo service auditd restart
                Severity:medium
                Weight:10.0
                Reference:
                Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                Publisher:DISA
                Type:DPMS Target
                Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                Identifier:5416
                Definitions:
                Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:293
                Result:false
                Title:OL08-00-030600 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any attempted modifications to the "lastlog" file.
                Description:Without the capability to generate audit records, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).

                The list of audited events is the set of events for which audits are to be generated. This set of events is typically a subset of the list of all events for which the system is capable of generating audit records.

                DoD has defined the list of events for which OL 8 will provide an audit record generation capability as the following:

                1) Successful and unsuccessful attempts to access, modify, or delete privileges, security objects, security levels, or categories of information (e.g., classification levels);

                2) Access actions, such as successful and unsuccessful logon attempts, privileged activities or other system-level access, starting and ending time for user access to the system, concurrent logons from different workstations, successful and unsuccessful accesses to objects, all program initiations, and all direct access to the information system;

                3) All account creations, modifications, disabling, and terminations; and

                4) All kernel module load, unload, and restart actions.

                Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215, SRG-OS-000473-GPOS-00218
                Class:compliance
                Tests:
                • false (All child checks must be true.)
                  • false (Audit modifications to /var/log/lastlog.)
                Tests:
                Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:29300 (textfilecontent54_test)
                Result:false
                Title:Audit modifications to /var/log/lastlog.
                Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:29300 (textfilecontent54_object)
                Object Requirements:
                • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
                • for pattern, the following must be true:
                  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-w\s+/var/log/lastlog(?:\s+-p\s+(?:[rx]*w[rx]*a[rx]*|[rx]*a[rx]*w[rx]*))?(?:\s+(?:-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
                • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                V-248806 - OL 8 must allow only the Information System Security Manager (ISSM) (or individuals or roles appointed by the ISSM) to select which auditable events are to be audited.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248806r779984_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Fail
                Version:OL08-00-030610
                Identities:CCI-000171 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 b; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 b)
                Description: Without the capability to restrict the roles and individuals that can select which events are audited, unauthorized personnel may be able to prevent the auditing of critical events. Misconfigured audits may degrade the system's performance by overwhelming the audit log. Misconfigured audits may also make it more difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one. false
                Fix Text:Configure the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" and "/etc/audit/auditd.conf" files to have a mode of "0640" with the following commands:

                $ sudo chmod 0640 /etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules
                $ sudo chmod 0640 /etc/audit/auditd.conf
                Severity:medium
                Weight:10.0
                Reference:
                Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                Publisher:DISA
                Type:DPMS Target
                Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                Identifier:5416
                Definitions:
                Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:294
                Result:false
                Title:OL08-00-030610 - OL 8 must allow only the Information System Security Manager (ISSM) (or individuals or roles appointed by the ISSM) to select which auditable events are to be audited.
                Description:Without the capability to restrict the roles and individuals that can select which events are audited, unauthorized personnel may be able to prevent the auditing of critical events. Misconfigured audits may degrade the system's performance by overwhelming the audit log. Misconfigured audits may also make it more difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.
                Class:compliance
                Tests:
                • false (All child checks must be true.)
                  • false (/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules has mode 0640 or less permissive)
                  • false (/etc/audit/auditd.conf has mode 0640 or less permissive)
                Tests:
                Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:29400 (file_test)
                Result:false
                Title:/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules has mode 0640 or less permissive
                Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:29400 (file_object)
                Object Requirements:
                • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules'
                State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:12100 (file_state)
                State Requirements:
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', suid must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', sgid must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', sticky must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', uexec must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', gwrite must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', gexec must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', oread must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', owrite must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', oexec must be equal to 'false'
                Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
                Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:29401 (file_test)
                Result:false
                Title:/etc/audit/auditd.conf has mode 0640 or less permissive
                Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:29401 (file_object)
                Object Requirements:
                • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/auditd.conf'
                State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:12100 (file_state)
                State Requirements:
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', suid must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', sgid must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', sticky must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', uexec must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', gwrite must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', gexec must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', oread must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', owrite must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', oexec must be equal to 'false'
                Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                V-248807 - OL 8 audit tools must have a mode of "0755" or less permissive.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248807r779987_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Pass
                Version:OL08-00-030620
                Identities:CCI-001493 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-9; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-9.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-9; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-9 a)
                Description: Protecting audit information includes identifying and protecting the tools used to view and manipulate log data. Therefore, protecting audit tools is necessary to prevent unauthorized operation on audit information.

                OL 8 systems providing tools to interface with audit information will leverage user permissions and roles identifying the user accessing the tools, and the corresponding user rights, to make access decisions regarding the access to audit tools.

                Audit tools include but are not limited to vendor-provided and open source audit tools needed to successfully view and manipulate audit information system activity and records. Audit tools include custom queries and report generators. false
                Fix Text:Configure the audit tools to be protected from unauthorized access by setting the correct permissive mode using the following command:

                $ sudo chmod 0755 [audit_tool]

                Replace "[audit_tool]" with the audit tool that does not have the correct permissive mode.
                Severity:medium
                Weight:10.0
                Reference:
                Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                Publisher:DISA
                Type:DPMS Target
                Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                Identifier:5416
                Definitions:
                Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:295
                Result:true
                Title:OL08-00-030620 - OL 8 audit tools must have a mode of "0755" or less permissive.
                Description:Protecting audit information includes identifying and protecting the tools used to view and manipulate log data. Therefore, protecting audit tools is necessary to prevent unauthorized operation on audit information.

                OL 8 systems providing tools to interface with audit information will leverage user permissions and roles identifying the user accessing the tools, and the corresponding user rights, to make access decisions regarding the access to audit tools.

                Audit tools include but are not limited to vendor-provided and open source audit tools needed to successfully view and manipulate audit information system activity and records. Audit tools include custom queries and report generators.
                Class:compliance
                Tests:
                • true (All child checks must be true.)
                  • true (Audit tools have mode 0755 or less permissive.)
                Tests:
                Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:29500 (file_test)
                Result:true
                Title:Audit tools have mode 0755 or less permissive.
                Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:29700 (file_object)
                Object Requirements:
                • for filepath, at least one of the following must be true:
                  • filepath must be equal to '/sbin/auditctl'
                  • filepath must be equal to '/sbin/aureport'
                  • filepath must be equal to '/sbin/ausearch'
                  • filepath must be equal to '/sbin/autrace'
                  • filepath must be equal to '/sbin/auditd'
                  • filepath must be equal to '/sbin/rsyslogd'
                  • filepath must be equal to '/sbin/augenrules'
                State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:29500 (file_state)
                State Requirements:
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', suid must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', sgid must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', sticky must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', gwrite must be equal to 'false'
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', owrite must be equal to 'false'
                Collected Item/State Result:
                [ true ]
                • filepath equals '/sbin/rsyslogd'
                • path equals '/sbin'
                • filename equals 'rsyslogd'
                • type equals 'regular'
                • group_id equals '0'
                • user_id equals '0'
                • a_time equals '1694618204'
                • c_time equals '1684911925'
                • m_time equals '1680333867'
                • size equals '742160'
                • suid equals '0'
                • sgid equals '0'
                • sticky equals '0'
                • uread equals '1'
                • uwrite equals '1'
                • uexec equals '1'
                • gread equals '1'
                • gwrite equals '0'
                • gexec equals '1'
                • oread equals '1'
                • owrite equals '0'
                • oexec equals '1'

                V-248808 - OL 8 audit tools must be owned by root.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248808r779990_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Pass
                Version:OL08-00-030630
                Identities:CCI-001493 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-9; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-9.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-9; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-9 a)
                CCI-001494 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-9; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-9.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-9; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-9)
                CCI-001495 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-9; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-9.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-9; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-9)
                Description: Protecting audit information includes identifying and protecting the tools used to view and manipulate log data. Therefore, protecting audit tools is necessary to prevent unauthorized operation on audit information.

                OL 8 systems providing tools to interface with audit information will leverage user permissions and roles identifying the user accessing the tools, and the corresponding user rights, to make access decisions regarding the access to audit tools.

                Audit tools include but are not limited to vendor-provided and open source audit tools needed to successfully view and manipulate audit information system activity and records. Audit tools include custom queries and report generators.

                Satisfies: SRG-OS-000256-GPOS-00097, SRG-OS-000257-GPOS-00098, SRG-OS-000258-GPOS-00099 false
                Fix Text:Configure the audit tools to be owned by "root" by running the following command:

                $ sudo chown root [audit_tool]

                Replace "[audit_tool]" with each audit tool not owned by "root".
                Severity:medium
                Weight:10.0
                Reference:
                Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                Publisher:DISA
                Type:DPMS Target
                Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                Identifier:5416
                Definitions:
                Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:296
                Result:true
                Title:OL08-00-030630 - OL 8 audit tools must be owned by root.
                Description:Protecting audit information includes identifying and protecting the tools used to view and manipulate log data. Therefore, protecting audit tools is necessary to prevent unauthorized operation on audit information.

                OL 8 systems providing tools to interface with audit information will leverage user permissions and roles identifying the user accessing the tools, and the corresponding user rights, to make access decisions regarding the access to audit tools.

                Audit tools include but are not limited to vendor-provided and open source audit tools needed to successfully view and manipulate audit information system activity and records. Audit tools include custom queries and report generators.

                V-248809 - OL 8 audit tools must be group-owned by root.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248809r779993_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Pass
                Version:OL08-00-030640
                Identities:CCI-001493 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-9; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-9.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-9; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-9 a)
                CCI-001494 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-9; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-9.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-9; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-9)
                CCI-001495 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-9; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-9.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-9; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-9)
                Description: Protecting audit information also includes identifying and protecting the tools used to view and manipulate log data. Therefore, protecting audit tools is necessary to prevent unauthorized operation on audit information.

                OL 8 systems providing tools to interface with audit information will leverage user permissions and roles identifying the user accessing the tools, and the corresponding user rights, to make access decisions regarding the access to audit tools.

                Audit tools include but are not limited to vendor-provided and open source audit tools needed to successfully view and manipulate audit information system activity and records. Audit tools include custom queries and report generators.

                Satisfies: SRG-OS-000256-GPOS-00097, SRG-OS-000257-GPOS-00098, SRG-OS-000258-GPOS-00099 false
                Fix Text:Configure the audit tools to be group-owned by "root" by running the following command:

                $ sudo chgrp root [audit_tool]

                Replace "[audit_tool]" with each audit tool not group-owned by "root".

                V-248812 - OL 8 must have the packages required for offloading audit logs installed.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248812r780002_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Pass
                Version:OL08-00-030670
                Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                Description: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

                Offloading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.

                OL 8 installation media provides "rsyslogd". This is a system utility providing support for message logging. Support for both internet and UNIX domain sockets enables this utility to support both local and remote logging. Coupling this utility with "gnutls" (which is a secure communications library implementing the SSL, TLS, and DTLS protocols) provides a method to securely encrypt and offload auditing.

                Rsyslog provides three ways to forward message: the traditional UDP transport, which is extremely lossy but standard; the plain TCP based transport, which loses messages only during certain situations but is widely available; and the RELP transport, which does not lose messages but is currently available only as part of the rsyslogd 3.15.0 and above.

                Examples of each configuration follow:
                UDP *.* @remotesystemname
                TCP *.* @@remotesystemname
                RELP *.* :omrelp:remotesystemname:2514

                Note that a port number was given as there is no standard port for RELP. false
                Fix Text:Configure the operating system to offload audit logs by installing the required packages with the following command:

                $ sudo yum install rsyslog
                Severity:medium
                Weight:10.0
                Reference:
                Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                Publisher:DISA
                Type:DPMS Target
                Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                Identifier:5416
                Definitions:
                Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:298
                Result:true
                Title:OL08-00-030670 - OL 8 must have the packages required for offloading audit logs installed.
                Description:Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

                Offloading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.

                OL 8 installation media provides "rsyslogd". This is a system utility providing support for message logging. Support for both internet and UNIX domain sockets enables this utility to support both local and remote logging. Coupling this utility with "gnutls" (which is a secure communications library implementing the SSL, TLS, and DTLS protocols) provides a method to securely encrypt and offload auditing.

                Rsyslog provides three ways to forward message: the traditional UDP transport, which is extremely lossy but standard; the plain TCP based transport, which loses messages only during certain situations but is widely available; and the RELP transport, which does not lose messages but is currently available only as part of the rsyslogd 3.15.0 and above.

                Examples of each configuration follow:
                UDP *.* @remotesystemname
                TCP *.* @@remotesystemname
                RELP *.* :omrelp:remotesystemname:2514

                Note that a port number was given as there is no standard port for RELP.
                Class:compliance
                Tests:
                • true (All child checks must be true.)
                  • true (The rsyslog package is installed.)
                Tests:
                Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:29800 (rpminfo_test)
                Result:true
                Title:The rsyslog package is installed.
                Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:29800 (rpminfo_object)
                Object Requirements:
                • name must be equal to 'rsyslog'
                Collected Item/State Result:
                [ not evaluated ]
                • name equals 'rsyslog'
                • arch equals 'x86_64'
                • epoch equals '(none)'
                • release equals '13.el8'
                • version equals '8.2102.0'
                • evr equals '0:8.2102.0-13.el8'
                • signature_keyid equals '82562ea9ad986da3'
                • extended_name equals 'rsyslog-(none):8.2102.0-13.el8.x86_64'

                V-248813 - OL 8 must have the packages required for encrypting offloaded audit logs installed.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248813r780005_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Fail
                Version:OL08-00-030680
                Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                Description: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

                Offloading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.

                OL 8 installation media provides "rsyslogd". This is a system utility providing support for message logging. Support for both internet and UNIX domain sockets enables this utility to support both local and remote logging. Coupling this utility with "gnutls" (which is a secure communications library implementing the SSL, TLS and DTLS protocols) provides a method to securely encrypt and offload auditing.

                Rsyslog provides three ways to forward message: the traditional UDP transport, which is extremely lossy but standard; the plain TCP based transport, which loses messages only during certain situations but is widely available; and the RELP transport, which does not lose messages but is currently available only as part of the rsyslogd 3.15.0 and above.

                Examples of each configuration follow:
                UDP *.* @remotesystemname
                TCP *.* @@remotesystemname
                RELP *.* :omrelp:remotesystemname:2514

                Note that a port number was given as there is no standard port for RELP. false
                Fix Text:Configure the operating system to encrypt offloaded audit logs by installing the required packages with the following command:

                $ sudo yum install rsyslog-gnutls
                Severity:medium
                Weight:10.0
                Reference:
                Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                Publisher:DISA
                Type:DPMS Target
                Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                Identifier:5416
                Definitions:
                Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:299
                Result:false
                Title:OL08-00-030680 - OL 8 must have the packages required for encrypting offloaded audit logs installed.
                Description:Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

                Offloading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.

                OL 8 installation media provides "rsyslogd". This is a system utility providing support for message logging. Support for both internet and UNIX domain sockets enables this utility to support both local and remote logging. Coupling this utility with "gnutls" (which is a secure communications library implementing the SSL, TLS and DTLS protocols) provides a method to securely encrypt and offload auditing.

                Rsyslog provides three ways to forward message: the traditional UDP transport, which is extremely lossy but standard; the plain TCP based transport, which loses messages only during certain situations but is widely available; and the RELP transport, which does not lose messages but is currently available only as part of the rsyslogd 3.15.0 and above.

                Examples of each configuration follow:
                UDP *.* @remotesystemname
                TCP *.* @@remotesystemname
                RELP *.* :omrelp:remotesystemname:2514

                Note that a port number was given as there is no standard port for RELP.
                Class:compliance
                Tests:
                • false (All child checks must be true.)
                  • false (package rsyslog-gnutls is installed)
                Tests:
                Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:29900 (rpminfo_test)
                Result:false
                Title:package rsyslog-gnutls is installed
                Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:29900 (rpminfo_object)
                Object Requirements:
                • name must be equal to 'rsyslog-gnutls'
                Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                V-248815 - OL 8 must take appropriate action when the internal event queue is full.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248815r877390_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Fail
                Version:OL08-00-030700
                Identities:CCI-001851 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-4 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-4 (1))
                Description: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

                Offloading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.

                OL 8 installation media provides "rsyslogd". This is a system utility providing support for message logging. Support for both internet and UNIX domain sockets enables this utility to support both local and remote logging. Coupling this utility with "gnutls" (which is a secure communications library implementing the SSL, TLS and DTLS protocols) provides a method to securely encrypt and offload auditing.

                Satisfies: SRG-OS-000342-GPOS-00133, SRG-OS-000479-GPOS-00224 false
                Fix Text:Edit the "/etc/audit/auditd.conf" file and add or update the "overflow_action" option:

                overflow_action = syslog

                The audit daemon must be restarted for changes to take effect.
                Severity:medium
                Weight:10.0
                Reference:
                Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                Publisher:DISA
                Type:DPMS Target
                Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                Identifier:5416
                Definitions:
                Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:300
                Result:false
                Title:OL08-00-030700 - OL 8 must take appropriate action when the internal event queue is full.
                Description:Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

                Offloading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.

                OL 8 installation media provides "rsyslogd". This is a system utility providing support for message logging. Support for both internet and UNIX domain sockets enables this utility to support both local and remote logging. Coupling this utility with "gnutls" (which is a secure communications library implementing the SSL, TLS and DTLS protocols) provides a method to securely encrypt and offload auditing.

                Satisfies: SRG-OS-000342-GPOS-00133, SRG-OS-000479-GPOS-00224
                Class:compliance
                Tests:
                • false (All child checks must be true.)
                  • false (/etc/audit/auditd.conf: overflow_action = syslog, single or halt)
                Tests:
                Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:30000 (textfilecontent54_test)
                Result:false
                Title:/etc/audit/auditd.conf: overflow_action = syslog, single or halt
                Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                State Operator:One or more item-state comparisons may be true.
                Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:30000 (textfilecontent54_object)
                Object Requirements:
                • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/auditd.conf'
                • pattern must match the pattern '(?i)^\s*overflow_action\s*=\s*(\w+)\s*(?:#.*)?$'
                • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:30000 (textfilecontent54_state)
                State Requirements:
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '(?i)^syslog$'
                State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:30001 (textfilecontent54_state)
                State Requirements:
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '(?i)^single$'
                State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:30002 (textfilecontent54_state)
                State Requirements:
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '(?i)^halt$'
                Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                V-248818 - OL 8 must take action when allocated audit record storage volume reaches 75 percent of the repository maximum audit record storage capacity.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248818r877389_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Fail
                Version:OL08-00-030730
                Identities:CCI-001855 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-5 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-5 (1))
                Description: If security personnel are not notified immediately when storage volume reaches 75 percent utilization, they are unable to plan for audit record storage capacity expansion. false
                Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to initiate an action to notify the SA and ISSO (at a minimum) when allocated audit record storage volume reaches 75 percent of the repository maximum audit record storage capacity by adding/modifying the following line in the "/etc/audit/auditd.conf" file.

                space_left = 25%
                Severity:medium
                Weight:10.0
                Reference:
                Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                Publisher:DISA
                Type:DPMS Target
                Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                Identifier:5416
                Definitions:
                Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:301
                Result:false
                Title:OL08-00-030730 - OL 8 must take action when allocated audit record storage volume reaches 75 percent of the repository maximum audit record storage capacity.
                Description:If security personnel are not notified immediately when storage volume reaches 75 percent utilization, they are unable to plan for audit record storage capacity expansion.
                Class:compliance
                Tests:
                • false (All child checks must be true.)
                  • false (/etc/audit/auditd.conf: space_left = 25%)
                Tests:
                Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:30100 (textfilecontent54_test)
                Result:false
                Title:/etc/audit/auditd.conf: space_left = 25%
                Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:30100 (textfilecontent54_object)
                Object Requirements:
                • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/auditd.conf'
                • pattern must match the pattern '(?i)^\s*space_left\s*=\s*([%\d]+)\s*(?:#.*)?$'
                • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:30100 (textfilecontent54_state)
                State Requirements:
                • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '25%'
                Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                V-248824 - OL 8 must not have any automated bug reporting tools installed.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248824r780038_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Pass
                Version:OL08-00-040001
                Identities:CCI-000381 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-7; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-7 a)
                Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

                Operating systems are capable of providing a wide variety of functions and services. Some of the functions and services, provided by default, may not be necessary to support essential organizational operations (e.g., key missions, functions).

                Examples of non-essential capabilities include but are not limited to games, software packages, tools, and demonstration software not related to requirements or providing a wide array of functionality not required for every mission, but which cannot be disabled.

                Verify the operating system is configured to disable non-essential capabilities. The most secure way of ensuring a non-essential capability is disabled is to not have the capability installed. false
                Fix Text:Configure the operating system to disable non-essential capabilities by removing automated bug reporting packages from the system with the following command:

                $ sudo yum remove abrt*
                Severity:medium
                Weight:10.0
                Reference:
                Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                Publisher:DISA
                Type:DPMS Target
                Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                Identifier:5416
                Definitions:
                Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:305
                Result:true
                Title:OL08-00-040001 - OL 8 must not have any automated bug reporting tools installed.
                Description:It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

                Operating systems are capable of providing a wide variety of functions and services. Some of the functions and services, provided by default, may not be necessary to support essential organizational operations (e.g., key missions, functions).

                Examples of non-essential capabilities include but are not limited to games, software packages, tools, and demonstration software not related to requirements or providing a wide array of functionality not required for every mission, but which cannot be disabled.

                Verify the operating system is configured to disable non-essential capabilities. The most secure way of ensuring a non-essential capability is disabled is to not have the capability installed.
                Class:compliance
                Tests:
                • true (All child checks must be true.)
                  • true (The abrt package or related packages are NOT installed)
                Tests:
                Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:30500 (rpminfo_test)
                Result:true
                Title:The abrt package or related packages are NOT installed
                Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
                Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:30500 (rpminfo_object)
                Object Requirements:
                • name must match the pattern '^abrt'

                V-248825 - OL 8 must not have the sendmail package installed.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248825r780041_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Pass
                Version:OL08-00-040002

                V-248829 - OL 8 must not have the asynchronous transfer mode (ATM) kernel module installed if not required for operational support.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248829r780053_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Fail
                Version:OL08-00-040021
                Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                Description: The ATM is a transport layer protocol
                designed for digital transmission of multiple types of traffic, including telephony (voice), data, and video signals, in one network without the use of separate overlay networks. Disabling ATM protects the system against exploitation of any flaws in its implementation. false
                Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to disable the ability to use the "atm" kernel module.

                Create a file under "/etc/modprobe.d" with the following command:

                $ sudo touch /etc/modprobe.d/atm.conf

                Add the following line to the created file:

                install atm /bin/true

                Configure OL 8 to disable the ability to use the atm kernel module.

                $ sudo vi /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist.conf

                Add or update the line:

                blacklist atm
                Severity:medium
                Weight:10.0
                Reference:
                Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                Publisher:DISA
                Type:DPMS Target
                Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                Identifier:5416
                Definitions:
                Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:308
                Result:false
                Title:OL08-00-040021 - OL 8 must not have the asynchronous transfer mode (ATM) kernel module installed if not required for operational support.
                Description:The ATM is a transport layer protocol
                designed for digital transmission of multiple types of traffic, including telephony (voice), data, and video signals, in one network without the use of separate overlay networks. Disabling ATM protects the system against exploitation of any flaws in its implementation.
                Class:compliance
                Tests:
                • false (All child checks must be true.)
                  • false (install atm /bin/true is set in /etc/modprobe.d.)
                  • false (blacklist atm is set in /etc/modprobe.d.)
                Tests:
                Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:30800 (textfilecontent54_test)
                Result:false
                Title:install atm /bin/true is set in /etc/modprobe.d.
                Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:30800 (textfilecontent54_object)
                Object Requirements:
                • path must be equal to '/etc/modprobe.d'
                • filename must match the pattern '.*'
                • pattern must match the pattern '^[ \t]*install[ \t]+atm[ \t]+/bin/true[ \t]*$'
                • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
                Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:30801 (textfilecontent54_test)
                Result:false
                Title:blacklist atm is set in /etc/modprobe.d.
                Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:30801 (textfilecontent54_object)
                Object Requirements:
                • path must be equal to '/etc/modprobe.d'
                • filename must match the pattern '.*'
                • pattern must match the pattern '^[ \t]*blacklist[ \t]+atm[ \t]*$'
                • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                V-248830 - OL 8 must not have the Controller Area Network (CAN) kernel module installed if not required for operational support.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248830r780056_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Fail
                Version:OL08-00-040022
                Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                Description: The CAN protocol is a robust vehicle bus standard designed to allow microcontrollers and devices to communicate with each other's applications without a host computer. Disabling CAN protects the system against exploitation of any flaws in its implementation. false
                Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to disable the ability to use the "can" kernel module.

                Create a file under "/etc/modprobe.d" with the following command:

                $ sudo touch /etc/modprobe.d/can.conf

                Add the following line to the created file:

                install can /bin/true

                Configure OL 8 to disable the ability to use the can kernel module.

                $ sudo vi /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist.conf

                Add or update the line:

                blacklist can

                V-248837 - OL 8 must be configured to disable the ability to use USB mass storage devices.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248837r818697_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Fail
                Version:OL08-00-040080
                Identities:CCI-000778 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-3; NIST SP 800-53A: IA-3.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-3)
                Description: USB mass storage permits easy introduction of unknown devices, thereby facilitating malicious activity. false
                Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to disable the ability to use the USB Storage kernel module and to use USB mass storage devices.

                $ sudo vi /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist.conf

                V-248840 - A firewall must be installed on OL 8.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248840r853847_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Pass
                Version:OL08-00-040100
                Identities:CCI-002314 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-17 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-17 (1))
                Description: "Firewalld" provides an easy and effective way to block/limit remote access to the system via ports, services, and protocols.

                Remote access services, such as those providing remote access to network devices and information systems, which lack automated control capabilities, increase risk and make remote user access management difficult at best.

                Remote access is access to DoD nonpublic information systems by an authorized user (or an information system) communicating through an external, non-organization-controlled network. Remote access methods include, for example, dial-up, broadband, and wireless.

                OL 8 functionality (e.g., RDP) must be capable of taking enforcement action if the audit reveals unauthorized activity. Automated control of remote access sessions allows organizations to ensure ongoing compliance with remote access policies by enforcing connection rules of remote access applications on a variety of information system components (e.g., servers, workstations, notebook computers, smartphones, and tablets). false
                Fix Text:Install "firewalld" with the following commands:

                $ sudo yum install firewalld.noarch
                Severity:medium
                Weight:10.0
                Reference:
                Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                Publisher:DISA
                Type:DPMS Target
                Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                Identifier:5416
                Definitions:
                Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:427
                Result:true
                Title:OL08-00-040100 - A firewall must be installed on OL 8.
                Description:"Firewalld" provides an easy and effective way to block/limit remote access to the system via ports, services, and protocols.

                Remote access services, such as those providing remote access to network devices and information systems, which lack automated control capabilities, increase risk and make remote user access management difficult at best.

                Remote access is access to DoD nonpublic information systems by an authorized user (or an information system) communicating through an external, non-organization-controlled network. Remote access methods include, for example, dial-up, broadband, and wireless.

                OL 8 functionality (e.g., RDP) must be capable of taking enforcement action if the audit reveals unauthorized activity. Automated control of remote access sessions allows organizations to ensure ongoing compliance with remote access policies by enforcing connection rules of remote access applications on a variety of information system components (e.g., servers, workstations, notebook computers, smartphones, and tablets).
                Class:compliance
                Tests:
                • true (All child checks must be true.)
                  • true (firewalld package is installed)
                Tests:
                Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:42700 (rpminfo_test)
                Result:true
                Title:firewalld package is installed
                Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:42700 (rpminfo_object)
                Object Requirements:
                • name must be equal to 'firewalld'
                Collected Item/State Result:
                [ not evaluated ]
                • name equals 'firewalld'
                • arch equals 'noarch'
                • epoch equals '(none)'
                • release equals '13.0.1.el8'
                • version equals '0.9.3'
                • evr equals '0:0.9.3-13.0.1.el8'
                • signature_keyid equals '82562ea9ad986da3'
                • extended_name equals 'firewalld-(none):0.9.3-13.0.1.el8.noarch'

                V-248841 - A firewall must be active on OL 8.

                Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248841r853848_rule
                Test Type:Automated
                Result:Fail
                Version:OL08-00-040101
                Identities:CCI-002314 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-17 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-17 (1))
                Description: "Firewalld" provides an easy and effective way to block/limit remote access to the system via ports, services, and protocols.

                Remote access services, such as those providing remote access to network devices and information systems, which lack automated control capabilities, increase risk and make remote user access management difficult at best.

                Remote access is access to DoD nonpublic information systems by an authorized user (or an information system) communicating through an external, non-organization-controlled network. Remote access methods include, for example, dial-up, broadband, and wireless.

                OL 8 functionality (e.g., RDP) must be capable of taking enforcement action if the audit reveals unauthorized activity. Automated control of remote access sessions allows organizations to ensure ongoing compliance with remote access policies by enforcing connection rules of remote access applications on a variety of information system components (e.g., servers, workstations, notebook computers, smartphones, and tablets). false
                Fix Text:Configure "firewalld" to protect the operating system with the following commands:

                $ sudo systemctl enable firewalld

                $ sudo systemctl start firewalld
                Severity:medium
                Weight:10.0
                Reference:
                Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                Publisher:DISA
                Type:DPMS Target
                Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                Identifier:5416
                Definitions:
                Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:315
                Result:false
                Title:OL08-00-040101 - A firewall must be active on OL 8.
                Description:"Firewalld" provides an easy and effective way to block/limit remote access to the system via ports, services, and protocols.

                Remote access services, such as those providing remote access to network devices and information systems, which lack automated control capabilities, increase risk and make remote user access management difficult at best.

                Remote access is access to DoD nonpublic information systems by an authorized user (or an information system) communicating through an external, non-organization-controlled network. Remote access methods include, for example, dial-up, broadband, and wireless.

                OL 8 functionality (e.g., RDP) must be capable of taking enforcement action if the audit reveals unauthorized activity. Automated control of remote access sessions allows organizations to ensure ongoing compliance with remote access policies by enforcing connection rules of remote access applications on a variety of information system components (e.g., servers, workstations, notebook computers, smartphones, and tablets).
                Class:compliance
                Tests:
                • false (All child checks must be true.)
                  • false (/usr/sbin/firewalld process is running)

                Title:/usr/sbin/firewalld process is running
                Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                Check:Result is based on check existence only.
